articles.title: Relevant Coursework
articles.contents:
At Miami University, the Business Analytics Major introduced me to: (a) descriptive analytics, (b) predictive analytics, and (c) presriptive analytics. Furthermore, I have developed my computational skills in R, Python, and JavaScript.
Data Visualization
Course Description: An introduction to the use of business intelligence and data visualization in organizations, with emphasis on how information is gathered, stored, analyzed, and used. Topics covered include business intelligence, data warehousing, data visualization, and data mining.

articles.title: Fadel's Portfolio
articles.description: Welcome to the website. I hope you enjoy it!
articles.contents:
Welcome to my Site
Welcome to my personal site! I am an aspiring data analyst. I enjoy solving real-world problems, combining my background in R and my training in business analytics. I am also passionate about learning new skills, reproducible research, and sharing my lessons learned with other data scientists. Check out my most recent projects in my Portfolio tab.
Let’s Collaborate
Sample text from Ijeamaka Anyene’s Distill Site.
Do you want to use one of my computational art pieces? Or do you need a new visualization? Interested in having me talk at your organization or group? Do you have an idea that doesn’t fit the previous questions?  Email me!
Education
BSc Information Systems & Business Analytics | Miami University, 2020
Experience
Analyst | Comapny Name | 2019-20Consumer Insights | CADS | 2019

articles.title: Other Projects
articles.contents:
A Retrospective Two-Stage Analysis of COVID Cases by County
Objective: The COVID-19 pandemic in the U.S. has exhibited a distinct multiwave pattern beginning in March 2020. Paradoxically, most counties do not exhibit this same multiwave pattern. We aim to answer three research questions: (1) How many distinct clusters of counties exhibit similar COVID-19 patterns in the time-series of daily confirmed cases?; (2) What is the geographic distribution of the counties within each cluster? and (3) Are county-level demographic, socioeconomic and political variables associated with the COVID-19 case patterns?
Methods: We analyzed data from counties in the U.S. from March 1, 2020 to January 2, 2021. Time series clustering identified clusters in the daily confirmed cases of COVID-19. An explanatory model was used to identify demographic, socioeconomic and political variables associated with the outbreak patterns.
Results: Three patterns were identified from the cluster solution including counties in which cases are still increasing, those that peaked in the late fall, and those with low case counts to date. Several county-level demographic, socioeconomic, and political variables showed significant associations with the identified clusters.
Implications: Some work on why other people should care.
